Legal_Issue: Whether the Senior Immigration Officer erred in assessing hardship under s. 25(1.3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1.3)
Evidence_Assessment: Generalized hardship claims dismissed; personal links to risks (FARC and Mexican gangs) not adequately considered
Legal_Rule: Under s. 25(1.3), H&C applications must assess undue, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship without duplicating refugee protection assessments
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal interpretation, reasonableness for factual application
Procedural_Issue: Misinterpretation of statutory criteria for hardship assessment
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous assessment of hardship by failing to consider personal risk factors and past experiences
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Failure to properly assess personal hardship constitutes procedural unfairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's past experiences with FARC and Mexican gangs, potential harm to applicant and child
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under IRPA s. 25(1.3)
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged the Officer's narrow interpretation of hardship
Court_Result: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports, risk documentation
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision, remand for reconsideration
Outcome: Remanded for reassessment of H&C application
Applicable_Process: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds application process
Governing_Rule: Statutory interpretation of s. 25(1.3) IRPA requiring assessment of undue, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
